trial_identification.studytitle: Combining a Caregiver Intervention With Aricept Treatment for Mild to Moderate Alzheimers Disease
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Combining a Caregiver Intervention With Aricept Treatment for Mild to Moderate Alzheimers Disease

interventions.interventions:
Behaviour - Psychosocial information, counseling, and support Treatment: drugs - Donepezil (Aricept)
Behaviour: Psychosocial information, counseling, and support
Treatment: drugs: Donepezil (Aricept)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Caregiver: Changes in depression, measured with the Beck Depression Inventory
primaryOutcome.timepoint: every 3 months for the first year, and every 6 months for the second year

primaryOutcome.outcome: Caregiver: Changes in social support satisfaction, measured with the Stokes Social Network Scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: every 3 months for the first year, and every 6 months for the second year

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient: Changes in cognition measured by ADAS-cog
primaryOutcome.timepoint: every 3 months for the first year, and every 6 months for the second year

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient: Changes in abilities with activities of daily living measured by ADCS-ADL
primaryOutcome.timepoint: every 3 months for the first year, and every 6 months for the second year

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Caregiver: Changes in reactions to patient behavior, physical health, family conflict and sense of mastery
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: every 3 months for the first year, and every 6 months for the second year

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Patient: Time to nursing home placement

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Individuals diagnosed with mild to moderate stage Alzheimers disease and their spouse caregivers
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Severe psychological or physical illness
- Unwillingness by either spouse to participate in all aspects of the study

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A unique multinational study was conducted simultaneously in the USA, England and Australia. The goals of the study were to answer two questions: Does psychosocial support for the family enhance the effectiveness of drug treatment for Alzheimer's disease? Is the added value of psychosocial support the same in all 3 countries?
